unnormalised: A Delhi court has ordered a stay on the demolition of a property located at 123, Karol Bagh, pending further hearing. The case, filed by Mrs. Kavita Sharma, alleges illegal encroachment by Mr. Rakesh Kumar on her ancestral land. Adv. Mehra, representing Mrs. Sharma, argued that the demolition order, issued by the MCD on 20/07/2024, was procedurally flawed.
normalised: A Delhi court has ordered a stay on the demolition of a property located at one hundred and twenty three, Karol Bagh, pending further hearing. The case, filed by Missus Kavita Sharma, alleges illegal encroachment by Mister Rakesh Kumar on her ancestral land. Advocate Mehra, representing Missus Sharma, argued that the demolition order, issued by the M-C-D on twentieth july two thousand and twenty four, was procedurally flawed.

unnormalised: The court, after reviewing documents presented by both parties, observed discrepancies in the MCD’s assessment. Specifically, the court questioned the basis for classifying the disputed area as “encroached” and ordered a re-evaluation within 2 weeks. It also directed Mr. Kumar to maintain status quo until the next hearing scheduled for 15/08/2024 at 10:30 AM.
normalised: The court, after reviewing documents presented by both parties, observed discrepancies in the M-C-D's assessment. Specifically, the court questioned the basis for classifying the disputed area as “encroached” and ordered a re-evaluation within two weeks. It also directed Mister Kumar to maintain status quo until the next hearing scheduled for fifteenth august two thousand and twenty four at ten thirty A-M.

unnormalised: This case highlights ongoing issues with property disputes in Delhi, especially those involving inheritance and unclear land demarcation. Legal experts say such civil cases clog the system, sometimes taking yrs to resolve, often hinging on decades-old records.
normalised: This case highlights ongoing issues with property disputes in Delhi, especially those involving inheritance and unclear land demarcation. Legal experts say such civil cases clog the system, sometimes taking years to resolve, often hinging on decades-old records.
